result.execSummary:
The defendant was charged with both OWI (5th or 6th) and Operating w/ PAC (5th or 6th). The defendant was found guilty of OWI (5th or 6th) and the other charge, Operating w/ PAC (5th or 6th) was dismissed by the court.

  • Joseph L. White was found guilty of OWI (5th or 6th), a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: $1,000.00 bond on file applied to past due court appointed attorney fees and interest.  Balance applied to the fine.  Remaining balance due of $1,835.80 to be paid in full by April 16, 2018.    Failure to pay any part of the fine and court costs will result in 30 days jail.
Sentence to start immediately.  May serve on EMP according to jail rules.

Per Statute 343.301(g) your operating privileges for operation of Class D vehicles will require that vehicles owned and/or driven by you be equipped with an ignition interlock device.  Must install a mandatory Ignition Interlock Device when defendant obtains an occupational license or regular license.  There is a $50 ignition interlock surcharge imposed.
Must attend and successfully complete an alcohol assessment and a driver safety plan.  You must also comply with any recommendations.

records.addlTxt: Associated with Charge #1

ADA Melissa Inlow appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in person and with Attorney Osborne.  Defendant plead guilty to Count 1, OWI 6th.  Joint recommendation for 1 year jail with EMP.  $1000.00  fine, plus costs.  36 mo DL rev & IID.  Alcohol assessment and driver's safety plan.  Count 2 dismissed, but read in for sentencing purposes.  Count 3 dismissed by operation of law.  Prior conviction confirmed by the court with the defendant and Attorney Osborne.    Court reviewed the charge and possible penalties of the count the defendant plead to.   Defendant understood. Court reviewed the plea questionnaire, constitutional rights and elements with the defendant.  Felony warnings given.  He understood.  Defense stipulated that there is a factual basis for the plea.   Court found that the defendant freely, voluntarily, knowingly and intelligently entered his plea and waived his constitutional rights.  Court found that a factual basis exists for the plea.  Found guilty of OWI 6th contrary to 346.63(1)(a).  Joint recommendation for:  1 year jail with EMP.  $1,000.00  fine, plus costs.  36 month driver's license revocation & IID requirement.  Alcohol assessment and driver's safety plan.  Defendant did not exercise his right to allocution. 

Court ordered:  1 year jail.  EMP allowed according to jail rules.  Start immediately.   $1,000.00  fine, plus costs.  Pay within 60 day.    Failure to pay any part of the fine and court costs will result in 30 days jail.  36 month driver's license revocation & IID requirement.  Alcohol assessment and driver's safety plan.    Court advised defendant of the DNA submission requirement.
Plea/sentencing hearing on February 15, 2018 at 02:30 pm.

Defendant shall not operate a motor vehicle on the highways until properly reinstated in the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant shall not consume any alcohol unless a physician states in writing that the defendant is alcohol dependent and complete withdrawal could endanger the defendant's health or life. In this case a doctor's excuse must be submitted to the Jackson County Clerk of Court or the Jackson County Jail within 48 hours of the bond being signed. Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, bar areas of restaurants, or where available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.  As a condition of your release, you must be available 24 hours per day, 7 days a week to submit to testing for alcohol when requested by a law enforcement officer or your probation agent. The defendant may submit to an alcohol test at the Jackson County Sheriff's Office or submit to a PBT by a law enforcement officer. Upon request, the defendant shall appear for and submit to testing within two (2) hours of the official's request.  Must provide his current mailing address to the sheriff's dept. prior to release
defendant appeared voluntarily.  Warrant quashed.  Cash bond reinstated.  Defendant to call Attorney Osborne after court.  Reschedule plea/sentencing.
ADA Melissa Inlow appeared for the State.  No appearance by the defendant for plea/sentencing.  Attorney Osborne appeared in court.  Defendant was aware of the plea date.  Warrant authorized.
FPT canceled and scheduled for PLEAS at request of Atty Robert Osborne; parties have reached an agreement.
Plea/sentencing hearing on January 31, 2018 at 10:30 am.
Final pre-trial on January 29, 2018 at 03:00 pm.

ADA Melissa Inlow appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in person.  Attorney Osborne appeared by telephone.  #1 trial on 2/15.  Attorney Osborne has been trying to contact the defendant.  He just called this afternoon. Has an appointment on Wednesday.  Requesting another FPT.  1/29 at 3 pm.  Defense to update the court with his new address.
Atty Robert Osborne approved to appear by phone for FPT; court will call him at # provided.
